channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Syrian Rebels May Have Used Sarin
item.description: United Nations human rights investigators have gathered testimony from casualties of Syria’s civil war and medical workers indicating that rebel forces have used the nerve agent.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: News Analysis: Terrorists Find Online Education for Attacks
item.description: Qaeda propagandists have provided online education to teach their devotees in the United States how to carry out smaller-scale solo attacks, like that of the Boston bombings.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:credit: David Longstreath/AP; Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, via EPA; AFP-Getty; Uncredited/FBI, via AP
item.media:description: From left, Timothy J. McVeigh, who bombed a federal building in Oklahoma City; Maj. Nidal Hasan, who is accused of killing 13 people in Fort Hood, Tex.; Faisal Shahzad, who planted a bomb in Times Square; and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who has been held in the Boston bombing.

item.title: Egypt Premier Qandil’s Motorcade Comes Under Fire
item.description: A man fired birdshot pellets at a motorcade escorting Prime Minister Hisham Qandi, and officials called it as an accidental episode of road rage.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Syria Condemns Israel for Air Assault Near Damascus
item.description: Israel would not confirm that it had carried out the airstrikes, but the four explosions near the Syrian capital demonstrated a firepower more potent than any seen before in the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Syrian Arab News Agency shows a bulldozer removing rubble on Sunday after an explosion in the Al Hama area of rural Damascus.

item.title: Nueva Germania Journal: German Outpost Born of Racism Blends Into Paraguay
item.description: Nueva Germania, founded in 1887 by German anti-Semites, now has many residents with German surnames who are indiscernible from other Paraguayans.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luis Fischer, who is of German descent, at his house near Nueva Germania.

item.title: Libyans Pass Law Excluding Qaddafi-Era Officials
item.description: Bowing to pressure from armed Islamists and other militiamen, the congress passed a law to exclude former officials of the Qaddafi era from public office.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Israeli Attacks on Syria Fuel Debate Over U.S.-Led Airstrikes
item.description: The United States, Britain and France discussed the possibility of American-led strikes privately in the days before the attacks linked to Israel, officials said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Free Syrian Army fighters in Damascus prepared to head to clashes with forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad on Sunday.

item.title: Extremists Pursue Mainstream in Pakistan Election
item.description: With a name change, a banned group is fielding candidates across Pakistan, and though few are expected to win Parliament seats, experts note flexing of political muscle.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maulana Abdul Khaliq Rehmani, whose group, Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat, is fielding candidates across the nation, spoke in Khalid Walid in Khanewal, a district of lush fields and poor farmers.

item.title: Germany’s Free Democrats Gather to Lift Flagging Image
item.description: The struggling junior partner in Germany’s coalition government with Chancellor Angela Merkel’s Christian Democrats held a party congress that offered an election plan intended to attract voters.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Malaysia’s Governing Coalition Retains Power
item.description: The coalition won a majority of seats in Parliament in national elections, but opposition parties claimed that the result was tainted by voting irregularities.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak celebrated with a prayer on Sunday after his coalition won a majority of parliamentary seats.

item.title: Strikes in Syria Linked to Israel May Be a Signal to Iran
item.description: Strikes on military warehouses and other installations in Syria appear to underscore Israel’s determination to keep advanced weapons out of Hezbollah’s hands.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers and tanks in the Golan Heights on Sunday, overlooking a Syrian town on the border. Recent airstrikes in Damascus have been linked to Israel.

item.title: Last Hope in Ruins: Bangladesh’s Race to Save Shaheena
item.description: The story of Shaheena offered the last bit of hope of finding anyone alive in what is now considered the deadliest accident in the history of the garment industry.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Taslima Akhtfer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph of Shaheena, who remained alive under the rubble of a collapsed building. The death toll has exceeded 600.

item.title: Letter From Washington: Honoring an Advocate of Gun Limits
item.description: Gabrielle Giffords, the former lawmaker from Arizona, is expected to receive the John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage award for the lobbying she and her husband have undertaken to pass tougher gun control laws.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: Slovenia Falls From Economic Grace, Struggling to Avert a Bailout
item.description: Easy credit, combined with crony capitalism and corporate mismanagement, fueled a banking crisis that threatens to make Slovenia follow the path of Cyprus.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Matej Leskovsek for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Alenka Bratusek, the new prime minister of Slovenia, faces fiscal crisis.

item.title: The Caucus: McCain Says Airstrikes in Syria Put Pressure on Obama to Act
item.description: Senator John McCain said recent airstrikes just outside the Syrian capital were likely to increase pressure on President Obama to offer more forceful support to Syrian rebels.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: Nigel Evans Denies Rape Accusations
item.description: Nigel Evans, a deputy speaker questioned by the police on Saturday, said that the accusations of rape and sexual assault by two men were “completely false.”
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: Kenneth Bae Is No ‘Bargaining Chip,’ North Korea Says
item.description: Washington has called for the release of Kenneth Bae, who was sentenced to 15 years for committing what North Korea called “hostile acts.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Divided Over Bangladesh
item.description: A look at two companies with different responses to the tragedy in Bangladesh.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
item.description: Best of long-form journalism this week.
item.dc:creator: By SRUTHI GOTTIPATI

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Australia Strives to Balance China and the United States
item.description: Reactions in the official Chinese media to Australia’s new defense White Paper on China, which is more conciliatory than a previous one, were low-key, if apparently approving. Reactions from ordinary Chinese, expressed online, were mixed but still often critical.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Australian prime minister, Julia Gillard, sharing a toast with her Chinese counterpart, Li Keqiang, during a meeting at the Great Hall of the People in April.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 4
item.description: Pressure on Merkel; new star of Iraqi politics; JP Morgan Chase under scrutiny; and Robert Diamond after the Libor scandal.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, center, in Berlin last week. Germany's economy is expected to grow modestly this year, a potential source of voter discontent in September's parliamentary elections.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Welcome to Erbil, Tourism Boom Town
item.description: Iraqi Kurdistan is something of an island of stability in a sea of trouble — so much so that the chief city of the non-Arab region has been named next year’s Capital of Arab Tourism.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: The citadel at Erbil, Iraq. The city has been chosen to be the Arab Capital of Tourism for 2014.

item.title: Palestinian Leader, Mahmoud Abbas, Seeks Support of China
item.description: Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, arrived in China just ahead of the Israeli leader Benjamin Netanyahu, but there were no plans for a meeting between the two.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Malaysians Flock to Polls in High-Stakes Election
item.description: The electorate has a stark choice: maintain a semiauthoritarian government that has brought modernity and economic progress or vote in a combative but untested opposition.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, the opposition leader, cast his vote on Sunday in the Malaysian state of Penang.

item.title: Obama’s Vow on Chemical Weapons Puts Him in Tough Spot
item.description: President Obama surprised aides last year when he called the use of chemical weapons in Syria a “red line,” a move that has complicated the American response to evidence that such arms have been used.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER, MARK LANDLER, DAVID E. SANGER and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: The Official Facebook page of President Bashar Assad, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Syria’s leader, Bashar al-Assad, right, surrounded by bodyguards on Saturday in Damascus for the inauguration of a statue dedicated to university “martyrs” who were killed in the country’s civil war, in an image released on his official Facebook page.
